<div _ngcontent-ng-c1532857962="" inline-copy-host="" class="markdown markdown-main-panel enable-updated-hr-color" style="--animation-duration: 400ms; --fade-animation-function: linear;" id="extended-response-markdown-content" aria-live="off" aria-busy="false" dir="ltr"><h1 data-path-to-node="0">Comprehensive Architectural Specification for Aurora-Genesis: Hypercomplex Algebra, Fractal Geometry, and Manifold Optimization</h1><h2 data-path-to-node="1">1. Executive Summary</h2><p data-path-to-node="2">The proliferation of high-dimensional, time-varying data in domains ranging from autonomous robotics to temporal knowledge graphs necessitates learning systems that transcend conventional Euclidean vector spaces. The <b data-path-to-node="2" data-index-in-node="217">Aurora-Genesis</b> system represents a novel architectural paradigm designed to address these challenges by synthesizing hypercomplex algebra, fractal geometry, and Riemannian manifold optimization into a unified deep learning framework. This research report provides an exhaustive, code-level implementation plan for the core subsystems of Aurora-Genesis, specifically focusing on <b data-path-to-node="2" data-index-in-node="595">Dual Complex (Dual Phasor) arithmetic</b>, deterministic <b data-path-to-node="2" data-index-in-node="648">N-dimensional Sierpinski centroid generation</b>, and <b data-path-to-node="2" data-index-in-node="698">K-Medoids clustering on the SE(3) manifold</b> utilizing dual-quaternion geodesic distances.</p><p data-path-to-node="3"><span data-path-to-node="3,0">Current deep learning methodologies often fail to capture the intrinsic geometric structure of physical and semantic transformations. For instance, representing rotations and translations in separate Euclidean vectors disconnects the coupled nature of screw motions found in rigid body dynamics.</span><span data-path-to-node="3,1"><span><response-element class="" ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER"><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><source-footnote _nghost-ng-c1509015928="" class="ng-star-inserted"><sup _ngcontent-ng-c1509015928="" class="superscript" data-turn-source-index="1"><!----></sup></source-footnote><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----></response-element></span></span><span data-path-to-node="3,2"> Similarly, random initialization of latent spaces ignores the hierarchical, self-similar structure often present in semantic data. Aurora-Genesis remedies these deficiencies by embedding data into algebraic structures that enforce valid physical and logical constraints by design.</span><sources-carousel-inline ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER" _nghost-ng-c1143186217=""><!----><span _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" hide-from-message-actions="" class="button-container hide-from-message-actions ng-star-inserted"> &nbsp; Mathematical Foundations of Hypercomplex and Fractal Systems</h2><p data-path-to-node="8">To appreciate the architectural decisions behind Aurora-Genesis, one must first understand the limitations of standard real-valued linear algebra in capturing complex, hierarchical, and dynamic relationships. The system relies on three distinct but complementary mathematical pillars: Dual Complex Algebra for signal processing, Fractal Geometry for structural initialization, and Lie Group Theory for manifold optimization.</p><h3 data-path-to-node="9">2.1 The Algebra of Dual Complex Numbers (Dual Phasors)</h3><p data-path-to-node="10">The Dual Complex number system, often denoted as <span class="math-inline" data-math="\mathbb{DC}" data-index-in-node="49"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6889em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbb">DC</span></span></span></span></span></span>, emerges from the tensor product of the complex numbers <span class="math-inline" data-math="\mathbb{C}" data-index-in-node="117"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6889em;"></span><span class="mord mathbb">C</span></span></span></span></span> and the dual numbers <span class="math-inline" data-math="\mathbb{D}" data-index-in-node="149"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6889em;"></span><span class="mord mathbb">D</span></span></span></span></span>. This algebraic structure is uniquely suited for modeling systems where a primary oscillatory signal (the phasor) is coupled with a secondary signal representing a rate of change, uncertainty, or tangent vector.</p><h4 data-path-to-node="11">2.1.1 Structural Definition</h4><p data-path-to-node="12">A dual complex number <span class="math-inline" data-math="z \in \mathbb{DC}" data-index-in-node="22"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; data-path-to-node="17">2.1.2 Geometric Interpretation: The Dual Phasor</h4><p data-path-to-node="18">In signal processing and electromagnetics, a standard phasor <span class="math-inline" data-math="A e^{j\phi}" data-index-in-node="61"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span style="margin-right: 0.0572em;" class="mord mathnormal mtight">j</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">ϕ</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> encodes the amplitude <span class="math-inline" data-math="A" data-index-in-node="95"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span></span></span></span></span> and phase <span class="math-inline" data-math="\phi" data-index-in-node="107"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ϕ</span></span></span></span></span> of a sinusoidal wave. A <b data-path-to-node="18" data-index-in-node="136">Dual Phasor</b> extends this concept to capture the dynamic evolution of the wave. If a phasor <span class="math-inline" data-math="P(t)" data-index-in-node="227"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.1389em;" class="mord mathnormal">P</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> evolves over time, its state at time <span class="math-inline" data-math="t" data-index-in-node="269"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6151em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span></span></span></span></span> and its velocity <span class="math-inline" data-math="\dot{P}(t)" data-index-in-node="288"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1702em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.9202em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.1389em;" class="mord mathnormal">P</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.2523em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.0556em;"><span class="mord">˙</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> can be encoded into a single dual complex entity: </p><div data-path-to-node="19"><div class="math-block" data-math="\mathcal{P} = P(t) + \epsilon \dot{P}(t)"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.0822em;" class="mord mathcal">P</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.1389em;" class="mord mathnormal">P</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1702em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ϵ</span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.9202em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.1389em;" class="mord mathnormal">P</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.2523em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.0556em;"><span class="mord">˙</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></div></div><p data-path-to-node="20"><span data-path-to-node="20,0"> In the context of the Aurora-Genesis system, this representation is pivotal for <b data-path-to-node="20,0" data-index-in-node="81">Temporal Knowledge Graph (TKG)</b> embeddings. Entities are not static points but evolving trajectories. The primal part represents the entity's current semantic state (position in the complex plane), while the dual part represents its "semantic velocity" or the rate at which its meaning shifts over time.</span><span data-path-to-node="20,1"><span><response-element class="" ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER"><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><source-footnote _nghost-ng-c1509015928="" class="ng-star-inserted"><sup _ngcontent-ng-c1509015928="" class="superscript" data-turn-source-index="1"><!----></sup></source-footnote><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----></response-element></span></span><sources-carousel-inline ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER" _nghost-ng-c1143186217=""><!----><span _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" hide-from-message-actions="" class="button-container hide-from-message-actions ng-star-inserted"> &nbsp; For complex-valued networks, Liouville's theorem restricts bounded entire functions to be constant, making standard holomorphic functions like sigmoid or tanh problematic if strict complex differentiability (Cauchy-Riemann conditions) is enforced globally. However, for Dual Complex numbers, the extension of analytic functions is straightforward via the Taylor series truncation property of dual numbers: </p><div data-path-to-node="23"><div class="math-block" data-math="f(c_p + \epsilon c_d) = f(c_p) + \epsilon c_d f'(c_p)"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0361em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">d</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0361em; vertical-align: -0.2861em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.1076em;" class="mord mathnormal">f</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; Applying <code data-path-to-node="24,0" data-index-in-node="83">tanh</code> to a dual complex tensor results in <code data-path-to-node="24,0" data-index-in-node="124">tanh</code> applied to the primal part and <code data-path-to-node="24,0" data-index-in-node="160">c_d * (1 - tanh^2(c_p))</code> applied to the dual part. This implicitly trains the network to optimize not just the mapping of the signal, but the mapping of its sensitivity (gradient), leading to more robust feature extraction.</span><span data-path-to-node="24,1"><span><response-element class="" ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER"><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><source-footnote _nghost-ng-c1509015928="" class="ng-star-inserted"><sup _ngcontent-ng-c1509015928="" class="superscript" data-turn-source-index="7"><!----></sup></source-footnote><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----></response-element></span></span><sources-carousel-inline ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER" _nghost-ng-c1143186217=""><!----><span _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" hide-from-message-actions="" class="button-container hide-from-message-actions ng-star-inserted"> &nbsp; <button _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" hide-from-message-actions="" aria-label="Learn More" aria-controls="sources" class="mat-mdc-tooltip-trigger button image-fade-on hide-from-message-actions" aria-expanded="false" jslog="220646;track:generic_click,impression" aria-describedby="cdk-describedby-message-ng-1-57" cdk-describedby-host="ng-1"><mat-icon _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" role="img" class="mat-icon notranslate symbol google-symbols mat-ligature-font mat-icon-no-color" aria-hidden="true" data-mat-icon-type="font" data-mat-icon-name="expand_more" fonticon="expand_more"></mat-icon></button><!----></span><!----><sources-carousel _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" hide-from-message-actions="" id="sources" _nghost-ng-c735525359="" class="ng-tns-c735525359-65 hide-from-message-actions ng-star-inserted" style="display: flex; visibility: hidden;"><div _ngcontent-ng-c735525359="" class="container ng-tns-c735525359-65 hide" jslog="220997;BardVeMetadataKey:[null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,[1,null,1]]"><!----><div _ngcontent-ng-c735525359="" class="carousel-container ng-tns-c735525359-65"><div _ngcontent-ng-c735525359="" class="carousel-content ng-tns-c735525359-65"><div _ngcontent-ng-c735525359="" data-test-id="sources-carousel-source" class="sources-carousel-source ng-tns-c735525359-65 hide ng-star-inserted"><!----></div><!----><!----></div></div><!----></div><!----></sources-carousel><!----><!----><!----></sources-carousel-inline></p><h3 data-path-to-node="25">2.2 Fractal Geometry and the Sierpinski Simplex</h3><p data-path-to-node="26">The second mathematical pillar of Aurora-Genesis is the utilization of fractal geometry for memory initialization. Standard deep learning initialization (e.g., Xavier or Kaiming) assumes a Gaussian or Uniform distribution of weights, effectively scattering points randomly in the high-dimensional latent space. While statistically sound for dense representations, this approach fails to impose any structural prior on the relations between memory slots.</p><h4 data-path-to-node="27">2.2.1 The N-Dimensional Sierpinski Simplex</h4><p data-path-to-node="28">The Sierpinski triangle is a classic example of a self-similar fractal constructed by recursively subdividing an equilateral triangle. Aurora-Genesis generalizes this to <span class="math-inline" data-math="N" data-index-in-node="170"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.109em;" class="mord mathnormal">N</span></span></span></span></span> dimensions, using the <b data-path-to-node="28" data-index-in-node="194">Sierpinski Simplex</b>. An <span class="math-inline" data-math="N" data-index-in-node="217"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.109em;" class="mord mathnormal">N</span></span></span></span></span>-simplex is the convex hull of <span class="math-inline" data-math="N+1" data-index-in-node="249"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.109em;" class="mord mathnormal">N</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> affinely independent points in <span class="math-inline" data-math="\mathbb{R}^N" data-index-in-node="284"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8413em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbb">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8413em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span style="margin-right: 0.109em;" class="mord mathnormal mtight">N</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p><p data-path-to-node="29">The fractal is generated by an <b data-path-to-node="29" data-index-in-node="31">Iterated Function System (IFS)</b> of similitudes. For a regular simplex with vertices <span class="math-inline" data-math="\{v_0, v_1, \dots, v_N\}" data-index-in-node="114"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">{</span><span class="mord"><span style="margin-right: 0.0359em;" class="mord mathnormal">v</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0359em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span style="margin-right: 0.0359em;" class="mord mathnormal">v</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span style="margin-right: 0.0576em;" class="mord mathnormal">S</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3117em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> are defined as: $$S_i(x) = \frac{1}{2}(x + v_i), \quad i \in {0, \dots, N}$$Applying these mappings recursively generates a set of points (centroids of the sub-simplices) that inhabit a fractional dimension. The Hausdorff dimension of an <span class="math-inline" data-math="N" data-index-in-node="407"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.109em;" class="mord mathnormal">N</span></span></span></span></span>-dimensional Sierpinski simplex is:</p><div data-path-to-node="30"><div class="math-block" data-math="D_H = \frac{\ln(N+1)}{\ln(2)}"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span style="margin-right: 0.0813em;" class="mord mathnormal mtight">H</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.363em; vertical-align: -0.936em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.936em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div></div><p data-path-to-node="31"><span data-path-to-node="31,0"> For example, for <span class="math-inline" data-math="N=2" data-index-in-node="18"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.109em;" For high-dimensional embeddings (e.g., <span class="math-inline" data-math="N=128" data-index-in-node="92"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.109em;" class="mord mathnormal">N</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">128</span></span></span></span></span>), the fractal dimension allows the system to populate the latent space with a structure that is "sparse" yet "connected," facilitating efficient retrieval and preventing the "curse of dimensionality" where all points become equidistant.</span><span data-path-to-node="31,1"><span><response-element class="" ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER"><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><source-footnote _nghost-ng-c1509015928="" class="ng-star-inserted"><sup _ngcontent-ng-c1509015928="" class="superscript" data-turn-source-index="8"><!----></sup></source-footnote><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----></response-element></span></span><sources-carousel-inline ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER" _nghost-ng-c1143186217=""><!----><span _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" hide-from-message-actions="" class="button-container hide-from-message-actions ng-star-inserted"> &nbsp; This separation creates natural boundaries for decision making and classification.</span><span data-path-to-node="34,1,0,1"><span><response-element class="" ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER"><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><source-footnote _nghost-ng-c1509015928="" class="ng-star-inserted"><sup _ngcontent-ng-c1509015928="" class="superscript" data-turn-source-index="3"><!----></sup></source-footnote><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----></response-element></span></span><sources-carousel-inline ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER" _nghost-ng-c1143186217=""><!----><span _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" hide-from-message-actions="" class="button-container hide-from-message-actions ng-star-inserted"> &nbsp; Many AI applications, particularly in robotics and 3D vision, deal with rigid body motions—combinations of rotation and translation. The set of all such motions forms the <b data-path-to-node="36" data-index-in-node="248">Special Euclidean Group SE(3)</b>, which is a Lie group and a smooth manifold.</p><h4 data-path-to-node="37">2.3.1 The Limitations of Vector Spaces</h4><p data-path-to-node="38"><span data-path-to-node="38,0">Treating elements of SE(3) as vectors in <span class="math-inline" data-math="\mathbb{R}^{12}" data-index-in-node="41"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbb">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">12</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> (rotation matrix + translation) or <span class="math-inline" data-math="\mathbb{R}^7" data-index-in-node="92"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbb">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">7</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> (quaternion + translation) and applying Euclidean metrics (L2 norm) is geometrically incorrect. The Euclidean mean of two rotation matrices is not necessarily a rotation matrix. The "straight line" between two poses in Euclidean space does not correspond to the most efficient physical movement (a screw motion).</span><span data-path-to-node="38,1"><span><response-element class="" ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER"><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><source-footnote _nghost-ng-c1509015928="" class="ng-star-inserted"><sup _ngcontent-ng-c1509015928="" class="superscript" data-turn-source-index="9"><!----></sup></source-footnote><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----></response-element></span></span><sources-carousel-inline ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER" _nghost-ng-c1143186217=""><!----><span _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" hide-from-message-actions="" class="button-container hide-from-message-actions ng-star-inserted"> &nbsp; <button _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" hide-from-message-actions="" aria-label="Learn More" aria-controls="sources" class="mat-mdc-tooltip-trigger button image-fade-on hide-from-message-actions" aria-expanded="false" jslog="220646;track:generic_click,impression" aria-describedby="cdk-describedby-message-ng-1-57" cdk-describedby-host="ng-1"><mat-icon _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" role="img" class="mat-icon notranslate symbol google-symbols mat-ligature-font mat-icon-no-color" aria-hidden="true" data-mat-icon-type="font" data-mat-icon-name="expand_more" fonticon="expand_more"></mat-icon></button><!----></span><!----><sources-carousel _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" hide-from-message-actions="" id="sources" _nghost-ng-c735525359="" class="ng-tns-c735525359-68 hide-from-message-actions ng-star-inserted" style="display: flex; A unit dual quaternion <span class="math-inline" data-math="\hat{q}" data-index-in-node="127"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; The algebra of dual quaternions naturally handles the coupling between rotation and translation. Crucially, the <b data-path-to-node="42,0" data-index-in-node="244">Unit Dual Quaternion</b> manifold is a double cover of SE(3), similar to how unit quaternions double cover SO(3).</span><span data-path-to-node="42,1"><span><response-element class="" ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER"><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><source-footnote _nghost-ng-c1509015928="" class="ng-star-inserted"><sup _ngcontent-ng-c1509015928="" class="superscript" data-turn-source-index="4"><!----></sup></source-footnote><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----></response-element></span></span><sources-carousel-inline ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER" _nghost-ng-c1143186217=""><!----><span _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" hide-from-message-actions="" class="button-container hide-from-message-actions ng-star-inserted"> &nbsp; In the context of dual quaternions, this is related to the logarithm of the relative transform. If <span class="math-inline" data-math="\hat{q}_{12} = \hat{q}_1^* \hat{q}_2" data-index-in-node="212"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; Deep Implementation of Dual Complex Arithmetic in PyTorch</h2><p data-path-to-node="49">This section details the implementation of the <code data-path-to-node="49" data-index-in-node="47">DualComplexTensor</code> class and associated neural network layers. PyTorch does not natively support dual numbers, so we must construct a custom tensor wrapper that leverages standard <code data-path-to-node="49" data-index-in-node="226">complex64</code> or <code data-path-to-node="49" data-index-in-node="239">float32</code> tensors while enforcing dual arithmetic rules.</p><h3 data-path-to-node="50">3.1 Data Representation Strategy</h3><p data-path-to-node="51">To maximize performance on GPUs (which are optimized for 32-bit floating point operations), we represent a Dual Complex tensor of logical shape <code data-path-to-node="51" data-index-in-node="144">(B, C, H, W)</code> as a real-valued tensor of shape <code data-path-to-node="51" data-index-in-node="190">(B, C, H, W, 2, 2)</code>.</p><ul data-path-to-node="52"><li><p data-path-to-node="52,0,0">The last dimension <code data-path-to-node="52,0,0" data-index-in-node="19">(..., 2)</code> separates the <b data-path-to-node="52,0,0" data-index-in-node="42">Primal</b> and <b data-path-to-node="52,0,0" data-index-in-node="53">Dual</b> parts.</p></li><li><p data-path-to-node="52,1,0">The second-to-last dimension <code data-path-to-node="52,1,0" data-index-in-node="29">(..., 2,...)</code> separates the <b data-path-to-node="52,1,0" data-index-in-node="56">Real</b> and <b data-path-to-node="52,1,0" data-index-in-node="65">Imaginary</b> components of the complex numbers.</p></li></ul><p data-path-to-node="53"><span data-path-to-node="53,0">Alternatively, utilizing PyTorch's <code data-path-to-node="53,0" data-index-in-node="35">torch.complex64</code> support allows us to reduce the rank by one: <code data-path-to-node="53,0" data-index-in-node="96">(B, C, H, W, 2)</code>. Here, <code data-path-to-node="53,0" data-index-in-node="119">tensor[..., 0]</code> is the primal complex part <span class="math-inline" data-math="c_p" data-index-in-node="161"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7167em; vertical-align: -0.2861em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">p</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2861em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, and <code data-path-to-node="53,0" data-index-in-node="170">tensor[..., 1]</code> is the dual complex part <span class="math-inline" data-math="c_d" data-index-in-node="210"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5806em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3361em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">d</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. This is the preferred approach for conciseness and integration with existing complex-valued modules.</span><span data-path-to-node="53,1"><span><response-element class="" ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER"><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><source-footnote _nghost-ng-c1509015928="" class="ng-star-inserted"><sup _ngcontent-ng-c1509015928="" class="superscript" data-turn-source-index="10"><!----></sup></source-footnote><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----></response-element></span></span><sources-carousel-inline ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER" _nghost-ng-c1143186217=""><!----><span _ngcontent-ng-c1143186217="" hide-from-message-actions="" class="button-container hide-from-message-actions ng-star-inserted"> &nbsp; eD) = AC + e(AD + BC) Note: Complex multiplication is commutative, so order of AC/CA doesn't matter unless we generalize to non-commutative algebras later. """</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">isinstance</span>(other, DualComplexTensor): A, B = self.primal, self.dual C, D = other.primal, other.dual <span class="hljs-comment"># Primal: A * C</span> primal_out = A * C <span class="hljs-comment"># Dual: A * D + B * C</span> dual_out = A * D + B * C <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> DualComplexTensor(torch.stack([primal_out, dual_out], dim=-<span class="hljs-number">1</span>)) <span class="hljs-keyword">elif</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">isinstance</span>(other, (<span class="hljs-built_in">float</span>, <span class="hljs-built_in">int</span>, <span class="hljs-built_in">complex</span>)): <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> DualComplexTensor(self.data * other) <span class="hljs-keyword">elif</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">isinstance</span>(other, torch.Tensor): <span class="hljs-comment"># Broadcast multiply</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> DualComplexTensor(self.data * other.unsqueeze(-<span class="hljs-number">1</span>)) <span class="hljs-keyword">else</span>: <span class="hljs-keyword">raise</span> NotImplementedError <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title">conjugate</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self</span>):</span> <span class="hljs-string">""" Dual Complex Conjugate (Standard): z* = A* + eB* There are other conjugates, but this is standard for phasors. """</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> DualComplexTensor(torch.conj(self.data)) <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title">norm</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self</span>):</span> <span class="hljs-string">""" The magnitude of a dual complex number is a dual number. |z| = |A| + e( (A. B) / |A| ) where (.) is dot product of complex vectors. For scalar z = a + ib + e(c + id): |z| = sqrt(|A|^2) + e * (Re(A * conj(B)) / |A|) """</span> A = self.primal B = self.dual mag_A = torch.<span class="hljs-built_in">abs</span>(A) <span class="hljs-comment"># Dual part of magnitude: (Re(A * B_conj) / |A|)</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Avoid division by zero</span> eps = <span class="hljs-number">1e-8</span> safe_mag_A = torch.clamp(mag_A, <span class="hljs-built_in">min</span>=eps) interaction = (A * torch.conj(B)).real mag_dual = interaction / safe_mag_A <span class="hljs-comment"># Result is a "Dual Real" number, stored as complex for consistency </span> <span class="hljs-comment"># (imaginary parts 0) or simple tensor stack.</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Here we return a tensor of shape (..., 2) self.primal B = self.dual inv_A = <span class="hljs-number">1.0</span> / A primal_out = inv_A dual_out = -B * (inv_A * inv_A) <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> DualComplexTensor(torch.stack([primal_out, dual_out], dim=-<span class="hljs-number">1</span>)) <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span data-test-id="code-content" class="code-container formatted ng-tns-c3098535048-54"><span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title">dual_tanh</span>(<span class="hljs-params">z: DualComplexTensor</span>) -&gt; DualComplexTensor:</span> <span class="hljs-string">""" Applies tanh to dual complex tensor. tanh(A + eB) = tanh(A) + e * B * (1 - tanh^2(A)) """</span> A = z.primal B = z.dual tanh_A = torch.tanh(A) <span class="hljs-comment"># PyTorch supports complex tanh</span> dtanh_A = <span class="hljs-number">1</span> - tanh_A * tanh_A primal_out = tanh_A dual_out = B * dtanh_A <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> DualComplexTensor(torch.stack([primal_out, dual_out], dim=-<span class="hljs-number">1</span>)) <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title">dual_sigmoid</span>(<span class="hljs-params">z: DualComplexTensor</span>) -&gt; DualComplexTensor:</span> <span class="hljs-string">""" Applies sigmoid to dual complex tensor. sig(A + eB) = sig(A) + e * B * sig(A) * (1 - sig(A)) """</span> A = z.primal B = z.dual sig_A = torch.sigmoid(A) dsig_A = sig_A * (<span class="hljs-number">1</span> - sig_A) primal_out = sig_A dual_out = B * dsig_A <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> DualComplexTensor(torch.stack([primal_out, dual_out], dim=-<span class="hljs-number">1</span>)) data-path-to-node="60">3.4 The Dual Complex Linear Layer</h3><p data-path-to-node="61">A standard linear layer <span class="math-inline" data-math="y = Wx + b" data-index-in-node="24"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.0359em;" In Aurora-Genesis, weights <span class="math-inline" data-math="W" data-index-in-node="79"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.1389em;" class="mord mathnormal">W</span></span></span></span></span> are also dual complex numbers, allowing the network to learn both static relations and dynamic evolution patterns simultaneously.</p><p data-path-to-node="62">The multiplication <span class="math-inline" data-math="W x" data-index-in-node="19"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.1389em;" class="mord mathnormal">W</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span></span></span></span></span> involves the interaction of weight primal/dual parts with input primal/dual parts. </p><div data-path-to-node="63"><div class="math-block" data-math="\begin{bmatrix} y_p \\ y_d \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} W_p &amp; This structure preserves causality in the dual channel: the "rate of change" depends on the current state, but the current state does not depend on the "rate of change" class="hljs-built_in">super</span>(DualComplexLinear, self).__init__() self.in_features = in_features self.out_features = out_features <span class="hljs-comment"># Initialize Primal and Dual weights separately</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># We use standard complex initialization for both</span> self.weight_primal = nn.Parameter(torch.randn(out_features, in_features, dtype=torch.complex64) * <span class="hljs-number">0.02</span>) self.weight_dual = nn.Parameter(torch.randn(out_features, in_features, dtype=torch.complex64) * <span class="hljs-number">0.02</span>) <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> bias: self.bias_primal = nn.Parameter(torch.zeros(out_features, dtype=torch.complex64)) self.bias_dual = nn.Parameter(torch.zeros(out_features, dtype=torch.complex64)) <span class="hljs-keyword">else</span>: self.register_parameter(<span class="hljs-string">'bias_primal'</span>, <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>) self.register_parameter(<span class="hljs-string">'bias_dual'</span>, <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>) <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title">forward</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self, x: DualComplexTensor</span>) -&gt; DualComplexTensor:</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># x_p: (Batch, In)</span> x_p = x.primal x_d = x.dual <span class="hljs-comment"># Primal Output: W_p * x_p + b_p</span> out_p = F.linear(x_p, self.weight_primal, self.bias_primal) <span class="hljs-comment"># Dual Output: W_p * x_d + W_d * x_p + b_d</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Use existing W_p for the first term</span> term1 = F.linear(x_d, self.weight_primal) term2 = F.linear(x_p, self.weight_dual, self.bias_dual) out_d = term1 + term2 <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> DualComplexTensor(torch.stack([out_p, out_d], dim=-<span class="hljs-number">1</span>)) </code></pre><!----></div></div></div><!----><!----></code-block><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----></response-element><p data-path-to-node="66"><span data-path-to-node="66,0">This layer is the fundamental building block of the Aurora-Genesis encoder, capable of processing dual phasor inputs for tasks like robotic state estimation or temporal link prediction.</span><span data-path-to-node="66,1"><span><response-element class="" data-path-to-node="67"><h2 data-path-to-node="68">4. Deterministic N-Dimensional Sierpinski Centroid Generation</h2><p data-path-to-node="69">In high-dimensional spaces, "random" initialization often results in points that are equidistant and clustered on the surface of a hypersphere (the "soap bubble" effect). Aurora-Genesis mitigates this by initializing memory states or cluster centers using a <b data-path-to-node="69" data-index-in-node="258">Deterministic Fractal</b>, specifically the N-dimensional Sierpinski Simplex. This ensures the latent space is populated with a structure that is self-similar and hierarchical by definition.</p><h3 data-path-to-node="70">4.1 Recursive Algorithm Derivation</h3><p data-path-to-node="71">To generate the centroids of the Sierpinski simplex at a recursion depth <span class="math-inline" data-math="D" data-index-in-node="73"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.0278em;" class="mord mathnormal">D</span></span></span></span></span>, we first need the vertices of a regular N-simplex.</p><h4 data-path-to-node="72">4.1.1 Generating Regular N-Simplex Vertices</h4><p data-path-to-node="73">A regular simplex in <span class="math-inline" data-math="N" data-index-in-node="21"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.109em;" class="mord mathnormal">N</span></span></span></span></span> dimensions has <span class="math-inline" data-math="N+1" data-index-in-node="38"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.109em;" class="mord mathnormal">N</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> vertices. We can construct this using an orthogonal basis in <span class="math-inline" data-math="\mathbb{R}^{N+1}" data-index-in-node="103"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8413em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbb">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8413em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span style="margin-right: 0.109em;" class="mord mathnormal mtight">N</span><span class="mbin mtight">+</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> (the standard unit vectors <span class="math-inline" data-math="e_0, \dots, e_N" data-index-in-node="147"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner">…</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span style="margin-right: 0.109em;" class="mord mathnormal mtight">N</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>) and projecting them onto the hyperplane <span class="math-inline" data-math="\sum x_i = 1" data-index-in-node="204"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mop op-symbol small-op" style="position: relative; top: 0em;">∑</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3117em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>. Alternatively, a recursive geometric construction is more numerically stable for embedding directly into <span class="math-inline" data-math="\mathbb{R}^N" data-index-in-node="323"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8413em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbb">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8413em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span style="margin-right: 0.109em;" class="mord mathnormal mtight">N</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p><p data-path-to-node="74"><span data-path-to-node="74,0">The algorithm implemented below uses the recursive construction where vertex <span class="math-inline" data-math="k" data-index-in-node="77"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.0315em;" class="mord mathnormal">k</span></span></span></span></span> has non-zero components only up to dimension <span class="math-inline" data-math="k-1" data-index-in-node="124"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7778em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.0315em;" class="mord mathnormal">k</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span the last vertex.</span><span data-path-to-node="74,1"><span><response-element class="" _ngcontent-ng-c3098535048="" class="animated-opacity ng-tns-c3098535048-56"><pre _ngcontent-ng-c3098535048="" class="ng-tns-c3098535048-56"><code _ngcontent-ng-c3098535048="" role="text" data-test-id="code-content" class="code-container formatted ng-tns-c3098535048-56"><span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title">regular_simplex_vertices</span>(<span class="hljs-params">N</span>):</span> <span class="hljs-string">""" Generates the vertices of a regular N-simplex centered at the origin with edge length sqrt(2). Returns: torch.Tensor of shape (N+1, N) """</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Start with an identity matrix in N+1 dimensions</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Vertices are e_0, e_1,..., e_N</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Map from R^{N+1} to R^N using Helmert matrix or Householder transformation</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># that maps (1,1,...,1) to the zero vector (or appropriate axis).</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Efficient Method:</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># 1. Create N+1 points in R^N.</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># 2. Use the property that dot product &lt;v_i, v_j&gt; = -1/N for i!=j (if normalized).</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Using the "Cartesian" construction for N dimensions:</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Vertices v_0 to v_N.</span> vertices = torch.zeros((N + <span class="hljs-number">1</span>, N)) <span class="hljs-keyword">for</span> i <span class="hljs-keyword">in</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">range</span>(N): <span class="hljs-comment"># Recursive formula for coordinates</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># derived from ensuring equidistance</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Current dimension we are filling is 'i'</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Set components for previous vertices (0 to i-1) in dimension i</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> i &gt; <span class="hljs-number">0</span>: <span class="hljs-comment"># All previous vertices get the same value in the new dimension to maintain symmetry</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># This logic is complex to implement iteratively.</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">pass</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Alternative: QR Decomposition approach</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Create a matrix with -1/N off-diagonal and 1 on diagonal (approx) </span> <span class="hljs-comment"># then decompose.</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Practical Approach for Aurora-Genesis: </span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Use the vertices of the standard simplex in R^(N+1) and project.</span> basis = torch.eye(N + <span class="hljs-number">1</span>) <span class="hljs-comment"># Center the simplex</span> mean = torch.mean(basis, dim=<span class="hljs-number">0</span>, keepdim=<span class="hljs-literal">True</span>) centered = basis - mean <span class="hljs-comment"># Use SVD to find the N-dimensional subspace</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># The points lie on the hyperplane sum(x)=1, which is N-dimensional.</span> U, S, V = torch.svd(centered.t()) <span class="hljs-comment"># The left singular vectors U (or V in torch.svd conventions) define the basis.</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># We take the first N components.</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Project:</span> coords = torch.matmul(centered, U[:, :N]) <span class="hljs-comment"># Normalize to desired scale (e.g., unit distance from origin)</span> coords = F.normalize(coords, p=<span class="hljs-number">2</span>, dim=<span class="hljs-number">1</span>) <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> coords </code></pre><!----></div></div></div><!----><!----></code-block><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----></response-element><h4 data-path-to-node="76">4.1.2 Recursive Centroid Generation Code</h4><p data-path-to-node="77">The core idea is to apply the Iterated Function System (IFS) to the initial centroid. For a simplex, there are <span class="math-inline" data-math="N+1" data-index-in-node="111"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.109em;" class="mord mathnormal">N</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> contraction mappings. Each mapping <span class="math-inline" data-math="T_i" data-index-in-node="150"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span style="margin-right: 0.1389em;" class="mord mathnormal">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3117em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; data-test-id="code-content" class="code-container formatted ng-tns-c3098535048-57"><span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title">generate_sierpinski_centroids</span>(<span class="hljs-params">n_dim, depth</span>):</span> <span class="hljs-string">""" Generates centroids for an N-dimensional Sierpinski Simplex. Args: n_dim (int): Dimensionality of the space (N). depth (int): Recursion depth. Returns: torch.Tensor: Shape ((n_dim+1)**depth, n_dim) """</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># 1. Get Base Vertices (N+1 points in R^N)</span> vertices = regular_simplex_vertices(n_dim) <span class="hljs-comment"># (K, N) where K=N+1</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># 2. Initial Centroid (Depth 0)</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># The centroid of the simplex is the origin (0,0...0) based on our construction</span> current_centroids = torch.zeros((<span class="hljs-number">1</span>, n_dim)) <span class="hljs-keyword">for</span> d <span class="hljs-keyword">in</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">range</span>(depth): new_centroids = <span class="hljs-comment"># For every existing centroid, spawn K new ones</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># moving towards each of the K vertices.</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">for</span> cv <span class="hljs-keyword">in</span> current_centroids: <span class="hljs-comment"># cv: (N,)</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Broad casting: (K, N) + (N,) -&gt; (K, N)</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># T_i(x) = (x + v_i) / 2</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># This represents the center of the sub-simplex.</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Scaling factor is 0.5 for standard Sierpinski.</span> spawned = (cv + vertices) / <span class="hljs-number">2.0</span> new_centroids.append(spawned) current_centroids = torch.cat(new_centroids, dim=<span class="hljs-number">0</span>) <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> current_centroids </code></pre><!----></div></div></div><!----><!----></code-block><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----></response-element><h3 data-path-to-node="81">4.2 Application in Aurora-Genesis</h3><p data-path-to-node="82">In the Aurora-Genesis system, these centroids initialize the <b data-path-to-node="82" data-index-in-node="61">Latent Memory Banks</b>.</p><ol start="1" data-path-to-node="83"><li><p data-path-to-node="83,0,0"><b data-path-to-node="83,0,0" data-index-in-node="0">Codebook Initialization</b>: In Vector Quantized (VQ-VAE) components, the codebook vectors are set to these centroids. This forces the discrete latent codes to adopt a hierarchical, sparse geometry from the outset.</p></li><li><p data-path-to-node="83,1,0"><b data-path-to-node="83,1,0" data-index-in-node="0">Fractal Dimension Analysis</b>: The system can estimate the "complexity" of an input signal by measuring its Hausdorff distance to the nearest Sierpinski manifold. If the signal requires high-depth centroids to be approximated, it is deemed "high-frequency" or "semantically complex."</p></li></ol><p data-path-to-node="84">The table below contrasts this initialization with standard methods.</p><div class="horizontal-scroll-wrapper"><div class="table-block-component"><response-element class="" data-path-to-node="86"><h2 data-path-to-node="87">5. K-Medoids Clustering on the SE(3) Manifold</h2><p data-path-to-node="88">While Sierpinski generation provides <i data-path-to-node="88" data-index-in-node="37">initialization</i>, the system must adapt to data distributions that evolve on the <b data-path-to-node="88" data-index-in-node="116">Special Euclidean Group SE(3)</b> (rigid body transformations). Standard K-Means is inapplicable here because the "mean" of rotations is not defined in Euclidean space. We implement <b data-path-to-node="88" data-index-in-node="294">K-Medoids</b>, which uses actual data points as centers, avoiding the need to compute Frechet means on the manifold. We utilize <b data-path-to-node="88" data-index-in-node="418">Dual Quaternions</b> for the metric calculations.</p><h3 data-path-to-node="89">5.1 The SE(3) Geodesic Metric</h3><p data-path-to-node="90">The distance between two poses represented by unit dual quaternions <span class="math-inline" data-math="\hat{p}" data-index-in-node="68"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6944em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">p</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.1667em;"><span class="mord">^</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1944em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math-inline" data-math="\hat{q}" data-index-in-node="80"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6944em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.0359em;" class="mord mathnormal">q</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.1667em;"><span class="mord">^</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1944em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is derived from the amount of "screw motion" required to align them.</p><p data-path-to-node="91">Let <span class="math-inline" data-math="\Delta \hat{q} = \hat{p}^* \hat{q}" data-index-in-node="4"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">Δ</span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6944em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.0359em;" class="mord mathnormal">q</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.1667em;"><span class="mord">^</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1944em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6944em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">p</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.1667em;"><span class="mord">^</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1944em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6887em;"><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">∗</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6944em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.0359em;" class="mord mathnormal">q</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.1667em;"><span class="mord">^</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1944em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. This represents the relative transformation. The scalar part of the primal quaternion of <span class="math-inline" data-math="\Delta \hat{q}" data-index-in-node="129"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">Δ</span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6944em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.0359em;" class="mord mathnormal">q</span></span><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="accent-body" style="left: -0.1667em;"><span class="mord">^</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1944em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> gives the rotation angle <span class="math-inline" data-math="\theta" data-index-in-node="169"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.0278em;" class="mord mathnormal">θ</span></span></span></span></span>. The dual part relates to translation <span class="math-inline" data-math="t" data-index-in-node="214"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6151em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span></span></span></span></span>.</p><p data-path-to-node="92">The rigorous geodesic distance on the manifold is: </p><div data-path-to-node="93"><div class="math-block" data-math="d_{geo}(\hat{p}, \hat{q}) = \sqrt{ \theta^2 + \lambda \|t\|^2 }"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1944em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord accent"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6944em;"><span class="" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span style="display: block;"><div _ngcontent-ng-c3098535048="" class="code-block-decoration header-formatted gds-title-s ng-tns-c3098535048-58 ng-star-inserted" style=""><span _ngcontent-ng-c3098535048="" class="ng-tns-c3098535048-58">Python</span><div _ngcontent-ng-c3098535048="" class="buttons ng-tns-c3098535048-58 ng-star-inserted"><button _ngcontent-ng-c3098535048="" aria-label="Copy code" mat-icon-button="" mattooltip="Copy code" class="mdc-icon-button mat-mdc-icon-button mat-mdc-button-base mat-mdc-tooltip-trigger copy-button ng-tns-c3098535048-58 mat-unthemed ng-star-inserted" class="mat-mdc-button-persistent-ripple mdc-icon-button__ripple"></span><mat-icon _ngcontent-ng-c3098535048="" role="img" fonticon="content_copy" class="mat-icon notranslate gds-icon-s google-symbols _ngcontent-ng-c3098535048="" class="animated-opacity ng-tns-c3098535048-58"><pre _ngcontent-ng-c3098535048="" class="ng-tns-c3098535048-58"><code _ngcontent-ng-c3098535048="" role="text" data-test-id="code-content" class="code-container formatted ng-tns-c3098535048-58"><span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title">dual_quat_geodesic_distance</span>(<span class="hljs-params">dq1, dq2, w_rot=<span class="hljs-number">1.0</span>, w_trans=<span class="hljs-number">1.0</span></span>):</span> <span class="hljs-string">""" Computes weighted geodesic distance matrix between two sets of dual quaternions. dq1: (M, 8) - [r_w, r_x, r_y, r_z, d_w, d_x, d_y, d_z] dq2: (N, 8) Returns: (M, N) distance matrix. """</span> M = dq1.shape N = dq2.shape <span class="hljs-comment"># Separate Primal (Real) and Dual parts</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Shape: (M, 4)</span> r1, d1 = dq1[:, :<span class="hljs-number">4</span>], dq1[:, <span class="hljs-number">4</span>:] <span class="hljs-comment"># Shape: (N, 4)</span> r2, d2 = dq2[:, :<span class="hljs-number">4</span>], dq2[:, <span class="hljs-number">4</span>:] <span class="hljs-comment"># 1. Rotation Distance (Geodesic on S3)</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># theta = 2 * arccos( | &lt;r1, r2&gt; | )</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Inner product: (M, N)</span> inner_prod = torch.matmul(r1, r2.T) <span class="hljs-comment"># Clamp for numerical stability (avoid NaN in acos)</span> inner_prod = torch.clamp(torch.<span class="hljs-built_in">abs</span>(inner_prod), <span class="hljs-built_in">max</span>=<span class="hljs-number">1.0</span> - <span class="hljs-number">1e-7</span>) theta = <span class="hljs-number">2.0</span> * torch.acos(inner_prod) <span class="hljs-comment"># 2. Translation Distance</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># t = 2 * d * r_conjugate</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># We need t of the relative transform, or just Euclidean dist of positions?</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># K-Medoids usually implies a metric space.</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># The geodesic distance on SE(3) couples them, but for clustering,</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># distinct metrics are often combined.</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Recover translation vectors t1 and t2 from dual quaternions</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># t = 2 * q_d * q_r_conjugate</span> <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title">get_translation</span>(<span class="hljs-params">r, d</span>):</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Quaternion multiplication: d * conj(r)</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># conj(r) = [w, -x, -y, -z]</span> r_conj = r.clone() r_conj[:, <span class="hljs-number">1</span>:] *= -<span class="hljs-number">1</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Hamilton product d * r_conj</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># We only need the vector part (imaginary part) of the result for translation</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># t = 2 * vec(d * r_conj)</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Simplified vector part of quaternion product (d, r_conj):</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># w = d_w*r_w - dot(d_xyz, r_xyz) &lt;-- Should be 0 for valid dual quat</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># xyz = d_w*r_xyz + r_w*d_xyz + cross(d_xyz, r_xyz)</span> d_w = d[:, <span class="hljs-number">0</span>:<span class="hljs-number">1</span>] d_xyz = d[:, <span class="hljs-number">1</span>:] r_w = r_conj[:, <span class="hljs-number">0</span>:<span class="hljs-number">1</span>] r_xyz = r_conj[:, <span class="hljs-number">1</span>:] t_xyz = d_w * r_xyz + r_w * d_xyz + torch.cross(d_xyz, r_xyz, dim=<span class="hljs-number">1</span>) <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> <span class="hljs-number">2.0</span> * t_xyz t1 = get_translation(r1, d1) <span class="hljs-comment"># (M, 3)</span> t2 = get_translation(r2, d2) <span class="hljs-comment"># (N, 3)</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># Euclidean distance between translations</span> <span class="hljs-comment"># dist_trans = ||t1 - t2||</span> dist_trans = torch.cdist(t1, t2, p=<span class="hljs-number">2</span>) <span class="hljs-comment"># Combined Metric</span> distance_matrix = w_rot * (theta ** <span class="hljs-number">2</span>) + w_trans * (dist_trans ** <span class="hljs-number">2</span>) <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> torch.sqrt(distance_matrix) </code></pre><!----></div></div></div><!----><!----></code-block><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----></response-element><h3 data-path-to-node="97">5.2 The PAM K-Medoids Implementation</h3><p data-path-to-node="98">Partitioning Around Medoids (PAM) is more robust than K-Means. We implement a vectorized version suitable for GPU execution within the Aurora-Genesis training loop.</p><response-element class="" ng-version="0.0.0-PLACEHOLDER"><!----><!----><!----><!----><!----><code-block _nghost-ng-c3098535048="" class="ng-tns-c3098535048-59 ng-star-inserted" style=""><!----><!----><div
